questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and COPD presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG is given below. Given his medical history, what is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism contributing to his ECG findings?

COPD: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

ECG: Electrocardiogram

choices.text: Increased automaticity in the sinoatrial node
Reentry circuits within the atrioventricular node
Ectopic foci originating from the pulmonary veins
Conduction delay due to bundle branch block

questions.solution:
The most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism contributing to atrial fibrillation in this patient, given his history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and COPD, is the presence of ectopic foci originating from the pulmonary veins.

Atrial fibrillation is a cardiac arrhythmia characterised by rapid, and irregular atrial electrical activation, resulting in loss of organized atrial mechanical contraction. These rapid and irregular electrical signals input into the atrioventricular (AV) node, which determines ventricular activation and rate. 

Option A: Increased automaticity in the sinoatrial node can cause sinus tachycardia, in contrast to atrial fibrillation, which primarily occurs due to ectopic foci. 

Option B: Reentry circuits within the atrioventricular node is characteristic of AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), not atrial fibrillation.

Option D: Conduction delay due to bundle branch block: This refers to ventricular conduction abnormalities and is not a primary mechanism for atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop:
questions.solution:
The graph depicts air flow limited during both inspiration and expiration leading to flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is seen in fixed obstruction of the central or upper airway.

The image below shows air flow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in nonfixed variable extrathoracic obstruction. eg. vocal cord paralysis, extrathoracic tracheomalacia, polychondritis, etc.

The image below shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in variable, nonfixed intrathoracic obstruction. eg. intrathoracic airway, bronchogenic cysts, or with tracheal lesions.

The image given below shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called the "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern. Eg. asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchiectasis, and bronchiolitis.

Saw tooth pattern of the loop consists of small, rapid oscillations in flow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumors of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, upper airway burns, and obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
The given diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 

The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.

  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Applied aspect:

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion. 

Other options:

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. There is widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment.

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by a progressive fibrotic change in the pericardium that causes it to thicken and calcify. This leads to impaired cardiac contraction and filling. This gives rise to fatigue, elevated JVP (rapid y descent), ascites, and pulsus paradoxus. ECG findings in constrictive pericarditis consist of non-specific T-wave abnormalities. 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by diastolic dysfunction of a non-dilated ventricle with, mildly decreased contractility and ejection fraction. It often present with right-sided heart symptoms like edema, ascites, and abdominal discomfort. A fourth heart sound is predominately heard than a third heart sound and is often associated with atrial fibrillation. JVP shows rapid y descent and may increase with inspiration. Kussmaul's sign is an indication of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding phase Ib of a cystometrogram?

choices.text: It is due to the elasticity of bladder
It is due to the plasticity the bladder has
The graph is flat due to the contractility of the bladder
Micturition occur at the start of Ib

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding phase Ib in the cystometrogram is that segment Ib is due to plasticity of the badder. Plasticity is the ability of an object to deform its shape without breaking.

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia- initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib- long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II- sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered.
  • The dotted line- pressure-volume relation if the micturition had not occurred.

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R. In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. Since the radius also increases because of the plasticity of the bladder, there is only a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full.

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

Micturition reflex is the result of sensory signals from the stretch receptors in the bladder wall, which are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then efferent signals conducts back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers.

The micturition reflex pathway is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Elasticity refers to the ability of an object to return to its original state after being deformed by an external force. Elasticity of bladder is responsible for the recoil shrinking of the bladder after micturition. 

Option C: Contractility is the ability to contract and increase the tension or decrease the length or dimensions. Contractility of the bladder is responsible for the voiding of urine. It doesn't contribute to the flat curve in Ib.

Option D: Voiding starts at the end of Ib and the start of II.

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below.  Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively of the same?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a positively/ right-skewed distribution where mean> median> mode. Hence, the mean, median, and mode must be 11, 9, and 7 respectively. None of the other options have such a sequence.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there are an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve.

In the image, the tail is located on the positive side of the graph (right side) and so it is a positively or right-skewed distribution. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is vice versa in negatively skewed distributions.

The mean in a positively skewed distribution is pulled up because of the relatively small number of very high scores. The mode is the most frequent and the highest point on the curve, while the median lies between the mean and mode. 

Other options:

Option A: Mean= median= mode is seen in a normal (unimodal) distribution.

Option C: Mean< median< mode is seen in a negatively skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: The following tympanogram denotes:

choices.text: A - Otosclerosis and B - Middle ear effusion
A - Normal and B - Middle ear effusion

questions.solution:
The given tympanogram shows A - abnormally low compliance seen in Otosclerosis and; B - no peak in compliance as seen when fluid is in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 47-year-old female was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ECG patient represents normal ECG without a pulse - i.e. the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA). 1mg epinephrine is the next best step in the management of this patient.

  • The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until more definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted.
  • The pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms all without a pulse. It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated.

Reversible causes of cardiac arrest:

5 H’s:

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
  • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

5 T’s:

  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Tamponade (cardiac)
  • Toxins
  • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
  • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitations. Her ECG strip is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Narrow complex tachycardia without visible P waves and sudden onset palpitations as shown in the ECG suggests AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). It is a type of Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings-

  • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia at 150 bpm (green arrows) - indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm.
  • No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
  • The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) (black arrow) and pseudo-S wave (II, III, aVF) (blue arrows). 

Carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal manoeuvre) will be the best next step in management as vagal manoeuvres can terminate approximately 10-20% of AVNRT.

Other options:

Option B: Atrial fibrillation (ECG given below)Rhythm is irregularly irregular. P waves are absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter (ECG given below)Rhythm is regular. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

Option D: Sinus tachycardia (ECG given below) Normal sinus mechanism precipitated by exertion, stress, concurrent illness

questions.text: A patient underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism. One year post surgery, the following ECG changes were seen. What is the immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome, i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position (shown in the image below).

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with

  • 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through the intravenous route.
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally.
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium.

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: The given image shows a normal His Bundle Electrogram (HBE). The deflection shown by the arrow indicates _______
questions.solution:
The arrow mark shows V deflection of HBE which indicates ventricular depolarization 

His bundle electrogram (HBE)

The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE.

It shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes transmission through His bundle

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

 

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: In the image given below, the weight and height of a child are plotted against his age in years. Identify the correct statement.

choices.text: WHO growth charts used now are developed by National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS)
Short stature is defined as a height below 5th percentile
Puberty in this child will be normal
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age

questions.solution:
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age, as seen in cases of constitutional delay.

As seen in the graph, the child was short initially, but the final height is within normal range. Hence, this child has constitutional delay.

Other options:

  • The WHO growth charts are based on Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS). National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) developed growth charts
  • were used in the past.
  • Short stature is defined as a height below the third percentile or more than 2 standard deviations below the median height for age and gender (<-2 SD) according to the population standard.
  • Puberty will be delayed in this child.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient presents with dizziness and chest pain. The ECG of the patient is given below. What is the pathophysiology involved in this condition?

ECG: electrocardiogram

choices.text: Conduction from atrium to ventricle with no AV nodal delay
Conduction from the atrium to the ventricle and reentry to the atrium
Autonomous functioning of the AV node
Retrograde conduction from ventricle to atrium

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG finding with delta waves suggest a diagnosis of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). The main pathophysiology involved in this condition is conduction from the atrium to the ventricle with no AV nodal delay. This is due to an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria and ventricles.

Other options:

Option B: Conduction from the atrium to the ventricle and reentry to the atrium is the main pathophysiology involved in atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT).

Option C: Autonomous functioning of the AV node is the main pathophysiology involved in junctional tachycardia.

Option D: Retrograde conduction from the ventricle to the atrium is the main pathophysiology involved in antidromic AV reciprocating tachycardia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of dizziness and syncope. The patient's ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows alternating periods of sinus tachycardia followed by sinus bradycardia, which is characteristic of tachy-brady syndrome. In this ECG, the initial tachycardia is followed by a long offset pause and a junctional escape rhythm.

Tachy-brady syndrome, is a subset of sick sinus syndrome. This syndrome typically presents with symptoms such as dizziness, syncope, and palpitations due to dysfunction of the sinoatrial node, resulting in episodes of tachycardia and bradycardia. 

In this condition, tachycardia is most commonly due to atrial fibrillation (but it is not always present) with alternating symptomatic bradycardia and offset pauses. The presence of tachy-brady syndrome is an indication for pacemaker placement.

Other options: 

Option A: Brugada syndrome refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death. The ECG abnormality that is potentially diagnostic is a coved ST-segment elevation by >0.2 mV followed by a negative T wave in more than one anterior precordial lead (V1-V3). This has been referred to as the Brugada sign.

Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving the presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles. ECG shows a short P-R interval <120 ms and a slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the delta wave.

Option D: Romano-Ward syndrome is a cause of congenital long QT syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1- c, 2- a, 3- d, and 4- b.

The different types of heart blocks are:

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

 

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.

 

  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays.  It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

 

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: Which of the following type of ion channels is predominantly responsible for phase 0 of the given action potential?
questions.solution:
The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 0 corresponds to the impulse/upstroke and, this is predominantly due to the opening of 'L' (long-acting) type of calcium channels resulting in an intracellular movement of the calcium ions down its electrochemical gradient.

The pacemaker potential consists of:

  • Phase 0 - this is an upstroke seen due to the opening of 'L' type, voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. This causes an influx of calcium leading to the upstroke.
  • Phase 3 - This is followed by the inactivation of the calcium channels and the simultaneous activation of K+ channels. This leads to the efflux of K+ bringing about repolarization.
  • Phase 4- As the K+ efflux is increased, the pacemaker fibre is pulled to a state of hyperpolarization. Once this state is reached, because of the high extracellular concentrations of the sodium ions, they tend to move slowly into the fibre, thus causing a slow rise in the RMP on the positive side.
    • As these sodium channels get activated in the state of hyperpolarisation they are called the "h" channel or funny channel. 
    • A similar type of calcium channel called "T" (transient) type joins together with the funny channels and completes this phase

The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. What is the treatment for the given ECG abnormality?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation. 

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

When the timing of electric current is adjusted according to the R waves or the QRS complex of the cardiac cycle, it is known as synchronized shock, which is administered in cardioversion. In ventricular fibrillation, because of irregular cardiac electrical activity, there are no R waves or QRS complexes to which the cardioversion can be synchronized. Hence, it is administered unsynchronized to the cardiac cycle.

 

Other options:

Option A - Magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de points. It is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. 

Options C and D - Synchronised cardioversion and rate control are used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF). AF has normal QRS complexes with variable atrial activity resulting in irregular P waves of varying morphology.

The below ECG depicts atrial fibrillation:

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Which of the following substances follow the transportation kinetics similar to the one marked by the arrow in the graph?
questions.solution:
The arrow marked in the above-given graph relating the concentration of substances and the rate of transport indicates simple diffusion. Carbon dioxide acts through simple diffusion.

Simple diffusion refers to the process of random movement of a substance along its concentration gradient and is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Facilitated diffusion refers to transporting the molecule from one side of the cell membrane to the other with the help of transport proteins called carriers. Molecules move from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration. No energy input is required when carrier proteins move substances in the direction of their gradients.       

The graph below shows the relationship between concentration gradient and rate of transport in simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion.

Option A: Glucose transport by the glucose transporter is an example of facilitated diffusion which moves glucose down its concentration gradient from the ECF to the cytoplasm of the cell.

Option C: Sodium-glucose co-transporter -1 (SGLT 1) is an example of secondary active transport where more than one substance is transported against the concentration gradient using a single transport protein. The image below shows the secondary active transport of sodium and glucose using SGLT 1.

Option D: The proton pump is an example of primary active transport that transports hydrogen ions by obtaining energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct inference from the following partograph?
questions.solution:
The above partogram shows the course of labor that has progressed normally.

According to this partograph:

  • The FHR is within normal range.
  • Amniotic fluid is clear.
  • Cervix went from 4cm dilated to fully dilated, and the head descended to zero station after 4 hours.
  • Contraction intensity and frequency progressively increased along with cervical dilation.
  • Oxytocin was not administered.
  • Maternal vitals and urine output were within normal range.
